title: not time discredit government coronavirus strategy
story: Instead, a handful of broadcasters used precious air time to promote a motley crew of “scientists” desperately hoping to make their names discrediting the Government’s strategy.To those who don’t understand virology, not taking the same draconian measures as other countries may seem odd.But the Prime Minister is acting on the advice of Sir Patrick Vallance and Chris Whitty — eminent doctors ideally equipped to deal with the pandemic.Of course, their superior expertise shouldn’t exempt them from all scrutiny.And, given the stakes, the Government MUST publish the details of its modelling to put minds at rest and give expert virologists a chance to have their say.But puffed-up PhD students with an axe to grind are a far cry from professional epidemiologists.And British broadcasters should know better than to let them spread panic.ACCESS to education is one of the pillars of a civilised society.But because schools are excluding weaker pupils to avoid poor results harming their position in the league tables, a growing number of children are denied that basic right.The consequences of this folly are enormous.It’s estimated that every year-group of permanently excluded pupils costs us £.billion extra on education, health and welfare benefits.And, just as worryingly,  per cent of children in young offender institutions had been excluded while  per cent of prisoners were suspended or excluded.We get that children who struggle academically can be tough on over-stretched teachers.But education shouldn’t be about survival of the fittest.And it’s often the weakest pupils who need school most.Dumping them on the scrapheap of society isn’t fair on anyone.AMID horror and uncertainty, British people are displaying extraordinary kindness, camaraderie and bravery.Each time the Government announces it’s taking another step to keep us safe, Brits have demonstrated that they are listening — and understand the gravity of the situation.Instead of complaining about missed holidays and football games, they’ve quickly and quietly got on with what needs to be done. Shopkeepers — worrying about their own futures — have given out free hand sanitiser and tinned goods to elderly locals.Neighbours have rallied around those most at risk from the disease.This — not needless shelf-clearing — is Britain at its best. Our journalists strive for accuracy title: coronavirus uk frontline nurses doctors ae staff working covid 19
story: THEY are the everyday heroes now working around the clock to keep us safe from coronavirus.And now NHS staff are facing one of the biggest tests of their careers, we want them to know how grateful the nation is for all they do.With overworked staff having to take on extra shts - and even being asked to come in when they are in self-isolation - and cut themselves off from loved ones to reduce any risk of infecting them, morale is at an all time low.Here, five heroic staff members have revealed what le is really like on the frontline, with the threat of personal protective gear running out of stock, fears they and their colleagues could be infected at any minute, and over-stretched wards already nearing capacity.Former Love Island star Dr Alex George works in the Accident and Emergency department at University Hospital, Lewisham and says a big spike in cases could cause the NHS to buckle.Dr Alex says: “Ive been testing around eight patients a sht - and the NHS can easily cope with that level, butwe start seeing  or  a day, the pressure will be on.The protective gear we have to wear at the moment adds to the queues at AE.Before seeing each patient I have to put on a gown, fit a mask and visor and double glove as well as the thorough hand-washing routine.We have protocols for taking off the gowns... and we have to change our scrubs between each patient.This is taking  minutes extra and tripling the time spent on each patient. In our AE department, we only have one isolation room for infectious diseases, with one bed, not the  or  beds you might imagine.If numbers rise, we would have to quarantine whole wards.Its good the government is going to put more money in - but you cant create more staff.At the moment, frontline staff are being offered extra shts and I know some who are working seven days a week.In the short term, you can do that. If this was going to be around for a month, everyone could take on a couple of extra shts.But this looks like it will be around a good few months and its very dficult to sustain that over a period of time, as it becomes unsafe for people to work.We have regulated hours because the longer youre working, the more tired you become and the more likely to make mistakes.What the NHS has always been good at is pulling together in a crisis. We are going to have to roll up our sleeves for the next couple of months until this settles, and morale is good at the moment.Butthis carries on for a long time, fatigue and stress will set in.If over the next six months, one in five people have it we can deal with it. Butfour in five people catch it, the NHS simply cant cope.Dr Rinesh Parmar, , is a speciality registrar in anaesthetics and intensive care in the West Midlands.Dr Parmar says: “It’s feeling really under pressure at the moment and there are frantic plans being made to try and prepare us.Were testing patients every day, but it takes over  hours for us to get a result.We have to assume anyone with breathing symptoms is positive and treat them as such - that’s increasing the workload dramatically. My colleagues are really stretched. There’s obviously so much pressure, but the problem we have is there’s a background of pretty low morale within the NHS anyway.Tap to see where COVID- is near youWe’re already short of staff on any given normal day without the pressure of the pandemic.The NHS has a tremendous ability to instil camaraderie amongst staff, but that’s really being tested at the moment because we all have our own anxieties.My parents are elderly, and they would be in the category where they’ve got underlying health problems, so I’ve stopped seeing them completely.Naturally we’re more susceptible to this, and because we don’t know who’s positive and who’s not, you could come across a patient, be treating them, and not be wearing the full protection.The other worry for doctors is that we’re being told there may be a rationing of personal protective equipment.Plus, the advice for the public [ they come into contact with someone whos infected] would be to self-isolate for seven days.But what’s happening with NHS staff is they start self-isolating, but then many of them have had a phone call asking them to come back into work... potentially becoming a risk to patients and other staff.They’ve spoken about cancelling annual leave for staff. That hasn’t happened yet but they’re compiling a list of volunteers.There’s also plans in place to redeploy other doctors, such as GPs, and bringing retired doctors back too.I worry that we’re leaving this too late for us [UK] to go into lockdown.We’re pretty full and although we can find physical space, the problem is we don’t have the staff.The government have said they’ll try to get more ventilators made, which is great and shows they’re listening, but we need healthy staff to come into work to be able to operate them.Our view is thatyou prioritise the testing of staff, then those of us that are negative can come back and we don’t have to self-isolate for seven days.Day by day we’re getting more and more prepared, but the problem will come when we’re overwhelmed on the unit and we’ve got staff going off sick. Then we’re really struggling.Dr Yaso Browne is a GP in a practice in Southampton. Dr Browne says: As we hear of more cases, our colleagues being affected, and knowing that we don’t have sufficient personal protective equipment, it makes us feel vulnerable.We support the efforts that are out there, but we’re all a bit fearful - we’re not currently being allowed to be tested unless we’re symptomatic.Also,we are, then actually we don’t get the test back in very good time.I think a bit more understanding about the testing, its supply, and what the capacity is would be hugely beneficial.For now, I think the feeling is we’re feeling vulnerable, rather than stressed. I sense people wanting to do something positive to try and help make us feel stronger, for our patients and for ourselves.I’ve actually chosen to limit my interactions with other people, because I’m worried that I’m high risk - so particularly limit interactions with those that I identy as more at risk.I think really it’s just more about trying to reduce the potential that you’re transmitting to family members. I do have loved ones that I’d worry about because they are at risk.But that’s also why you’d want to knowyou’ve had COVID, because then you’d probably be more able to have those social interactions.We haven’t seen any obvious solutions yet, so it is a really worrying issue for all of us.”Or you can like our coronavirus Facebook page here: https:www.facebook CoronavirusLatestTheSun Leaanne Pallant is a -year-old agency nurse in Hertfordshire. She is married to teacher Richard, and has two children, Poppy, seven and Isla, nine.She says: “On Sunday I worked on an isolation ward where  patients were being tested for the virus and a few were struggling to breathe.There was one case of coronavirus in the hospital at that time, in the Intensive Care Unit , and one case on our ward who was strongly suspected of having it.It was quite scary seeing the specialists dressed in the full-on protective gear. It really hit home that this is getting pretty serious now.All the patients are in separate isolation rooms and nurses or healthcare professionals are having to glove and gown and mask up before we go into that room.Then we have very strict degloving, taking your apron off and then washing your hands in a particular way, to protect yourself.We also have to have a runner so we don’t have to take everything offwe need something brought in, and drug charts are banned, so we’re almost doing patient identication through the window before administering drugs.The NHS was stretched before this, but the coronavirus is putting extra strain on it.As an agency nurse, who fills in on an ad hoc basis, there are a ridiculous amount of shts being advertised out and a lot of people dont want to put themselves in that situation.So nurses are actually cancelling extra shts that they dont have to be doing.I dont worry about myself catching the virus because Im  and I think my immune system is pretty tip top, and the children don’t have any underlying health issues.But  I have an elderly nan who I try and see once or twice a week. Ive had to say to her, ‘Sorry Nanyou need me to do an online shop for you I will but other than that, Im not going to be coming to see you,’ because I could have it and not know.I would never forgive myselfI gave it to her. So there is a lot of trying to distance myself and just be sensible, under the circumstances.As nurses, were exposed to a lot of bugs and viruses and its part and parcel of the job but this is an unknown virus so there are a lot of questions we don’t know the answer to.I went to do my normal weekly shop today and theres literally nothing on some shelves. It was post-apocalyptic.But le has to go on, and all we can really do is try and protect the people that need protecting.The country as a whole is doing what they can and what they need to do.I just hope that everybody is understanding and does isolatethey need to rather than being stupid about it.  Because it could be those few stupid people that ruin it for the majority.”Dr Robert Hirst, , works as an emergency medicine trainee in Bristol. He says: We have a few COVID patients here now, and theres a few more coming in.Were cancelling elective surgeries from Thursday here and just moving to emergency and cancer surgeries primarily.Weve been told were going to be redeployed to whoever needs us in the coming weeks - I imagine Ill be moving into the emergency department or intensive care soon.Its tense at the moment, its quite unknown and we all sort of feel like were at the beginning of something... its probably going to get worse before it gets better.Ive seen emails from other trusts saying the previous advice given doesnt apply to healthcare workers... but luckily no-one has been called in here from self-isolation yet.Its going to be a prolonged process here, it could be six months, there could be another peak in the winter, theyre having to be more sustainable with this.If this was a one-off major event, wed all be called in and it would be all hands on deck for a few days, but this is longer.A main concern for me is I live with my girlfriend and Im worried I could bring my work home with me in a very unpleasant way.Fundamentally wed be fine, but its the chance we could pass it on to my grandparents. We were supposed to meet them this weekend for my birthday but were having to hold off.Normally when you suit up its protection for the patients, but now its protection for the patients and for yourself and anyone  you come into contact with.I know a lot of people are concerned and we hear lots of rumours of young doctors being ill or in intensive care, or even have passed away, so I know its something that weighs on peoples lives.This very much could go downhill, but we just dont know yet.Dr Murray Ellender is a London GP and co-founder of eConsult. “GPs are having to think about fundamentally changing the way we work, and coming up with ways of managing the patients without them necessarily coming into the building.It’s disrupting the model of general practice - which is probably not a bad thing - but it’s happening faster than we would have expected or hoped.There’s a lot of worry about coronavirus and people with respiratory symptoms, but we’ve also got the everyday general practice with people coming in needing repeat prescriptions or with other health conditions.We’re having to manage the normal day job as well as people presenting with respiratory problems.It’s putting all sorts of pressures on the system and there’s the added concern of how we look after the workforce.If you’ve got a practice that’s got four or five GPs, you might have one who’s pregnant who’s now been advised they shouldn’t be at work, what impact does that have on the rest of the practice staff We’re having to manage increased demand with perhaps a slightly diminished workforce.Most GP practices, which have around , patients typically, are now looking at how they can work together when doctors are having to go into isolation.I’ve got a couple of colleagues who’ve had confirmed coronavirus. One of my partners is Clare Gerada, who’s been in ious press at the weekend talking about her experience of the illness.We have others who are now in isolation because they’ve either got symptoms or are pregnant.What we’re thinking through now is, ‘How can we still make use of their expertise and get them working from home ’Anyone who is in isolation who is feeling well enough to work can use a laptop to deal with certain patient queries remotely. And actually that helps them support the wider system.The system we founded, eConsult, is used in around , practices across the UK with half of all practices using that or a similar online consultation system.But half the country has nothing and the NHS is scrambling to make online consultation available to everyone.Practices are now asking, ‘How can we get this  And fast ’Last year, we were bringing about  practices a month on board. In the last couple of weeks, we’ve been bringing about  practices a day. It’s just gone nuts.There is a certain amount of fear amongst clinicians as well as the general public.We have some who’ve got long-term conditions or are the carers for elderly relatives.As so often happens, we don’t do enough in any society to look after healthcare workers. And they don’t tend to be very good at being looked after either - they tend to make very bad patients!”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc sport relief charity finishes
story: The first was to postpone it, like the football and rugby, until such time as the theatre plugs and worthy schemes about “bringing the outside world to pensioners” with breathing dficulties, looked a bit less reckless.The second was to say: “Stuff it, as a one-off gesture to the British public, at this time of crisis, every single penny raised will be spent in Britain.”But Auntie would no more do that than re-run all eight series of Love Thy Neighbour, in The One Show’s slot.So they took option C and just ploughed on regardless, from pm, Friday, with the usual too-many-cooks line-up of Paddy McGuinness, Alex Scott and Gary Lineker, who made this earnest pledge: “We promise we’ll spend tonight’s money with such care on the most vulnerable.”Well, you’d hope so, wouldn’t you. And you’d also hope they take more care than they did with the actual production, which started to betray a “will-this-do ” attitude with almost its first caption of the night.“Dermot Munaghan.” And the next one: “Colston Smith.” .A foretaste of what was to come, because the event had technically unravelled within the first hour when Lineker had to introduce a comedy sketch about VAR and the  World Cup final.First it appeared, then it vanished. So Lineker explained the punchline: VAR had not just found in England’s favour it had decided to award the  World Cup to Scotlandand Euro  to Wales.Then the sketch suddenly reappeared again and took six minutes to reach its bloody, teeth-pulling conclusion: “I’m going to change my name to Jamie VAR-dy.”In such circumstances, you can sit and hope the rest of Sport Relief moves, inspires and thrills with a perfect blend of laughter, compassion and entertainment.And I can also hope Scotland are going to win the next World Cup. It ain’t going to happen.Sport Relief is never ever over quickly, ’cos there are a whole load of BBC formats to be put through the ringer, like Line Of Duty, and far too much dancing, featuring everyone from Lineker and McGuinnes to a “social media influencer”, called “HRVY”, which wasn’t another spelling mistake. I think he’s just an RSHOL.At ious other points in this back-of-a-fag-packet evening: Hockey player Sam Quek took , football penalties against a short fat bloke, from point-blank range, and contrived to miss more than a quarter of them. Mel Giedroyc farted on a Question Of Sport special. Rylan accused Romesh Ranganathan of being over-exposed, before playing Andy Murray at crazy golf. And they flagged up an Action Line number, for people who were feeling “emotionally vulnerable”, after the Killing Steves parody, which may have been the most benevolent gesture in the event’s history.What really irks about Sport Relief, though, is that, evencompassion fatigue has never been more of a problem, they’ve decided it’s a triumph before it’s broadcast and the “Best Bits” Sunday show is all ready to go.Corporate backing also means there’s little risk of them not beating the previous total either, which, I hope, doesn’t sound like I’m diminishing the sincere efforts of the public.If there’s one thing I’ll remember about Sport Relief , however, it’s the contribution of David Beckham, who, infor a y advertorial for his new MLS franchise and some crashing product placement , offered two entire people the chance to attend an Inter Miami game and win a shirt signed by such global talents as Lewis Morgan and A J DeLaGarza, who’s played  entire games for Guam.There are moments when the generosity and humanity of celebrities simply overwhelms me.This wasn’t one of those moments.Bloke.CHANNEL  seemed to have all bases covered for its hugely entertaining new dating show Five Guys A Week, at least in terms of complete bellends.So, crammed into a semi-detached house in St Albans, hoping to win the heart of its owner Amy, it had: Christian, whose job “isn’t as glamorous as it sounds” . Uber-woke Glen, from accounts. A stuntman called Michael, who seemed to have mistaken the show for SAS: Who Dares Wins and voluntarily withdrew on day two. Mad, goggle-eyed surfer Trystan, who appeared to be casing the joint for a “kill room”. And the lowest form of le known to any single thirtysomething man – the bloke with the acoustic guitar, Scott, who used to be a bank manager, but now earns a living as a country and western singer and will be performing under the stage name Johnny Cashpoint,he’s got an ounce of sense.The five were chosen for their ability to get right on the viewers’ nerves rather than real boyfriend potential, obviously.And it made for a cracking hour of TV, because they all competitively fancied the pants off Amy, who looked like a younger and much hotter Camilla Parker Bowles,you can imagine such a thing.The show’s greatest strength, of course, is also its biggest format failing, as I’d imagine no one wanted any of them to win.In the event, however, it came down to a straight fight between the lesser of two evils and, probably wisely, Amy chose cocky Christian, who’s looking to whisk her off for breakfast in France, ahead of grovelling Glen, who, rather than looking for “the Michelle Obama to my Barack”, should probably be aiming for the Michelle Collins to his Ian Beale.Five Guys A Week, C, tonight, .pm.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What caused the cancellation of six Wimbledon championships in the s ”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in north-east England shares its common name with the body of a ship ”Spin To Win, Phillip Schofield: “What Saturday night TV show is Anton du Beke most famous for ”Hunted, Dan: “Who painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel ”LISA NANDY wasn’t born stupid. She volunteered to be, by standing for Labour Party leader.It means noisily backing every woke cause of the day, until their interests collide, as they did spectacularly on last Tuesday’s Good Morning Britain, where Piers Morgan hit her with two innocuous-sounding questions.“Are babies born either male or female ” and “Would you be happyUsain Bolt and Floyd Mayweather self-identied as women, spent a year having testosterone treatment and competed against women ”Correct answers: Yes and no.But Lisa couldn’t say that for fear of offending either the transgender or feminist lobbies.So instead she blathered, lied, evaded, shouted, demanded an apology from Piers , accused him of laughing and describing transgender people as “grotesque”and at one point muttered: “I don’t know what . . . I don’t know what, well, you know, I don’t know what.”Others would’ve let her off the hook at that point, as she was almost crying at her own stupidity by then. Chunk didn’t.To his eternal credit he ignored two ad breaks and kept up the pressure for a spellbinding  minutes that only ended when Nandy offered to settle the issue of whether Floyd Mayweather should be able to box women by “setting up a commission”.To which Piers responded: “It’s not a commission issue, it’s a common sense issue.”But that, as a wise man once said, is the problem with common sense, Piers. It’s not all that common.Ian Wright: “At this stage, I think three points is three points.”Jamie Redknapp: “Switching off from football is always beneficial sometimes.”Piers Morgan effectively ending Lisa Nandy’s Labour leadership bid on TV’s most consistently entertaining show, Good Morning Britain.Saturday night eye balm from BBC’s Ireland: Edge Of The World. Larry David ending up in the “ugly section” of Tiato’s restaurant, on Curb Your Enthusiasm.Sky’s Breeders managing to make a comedy about children bearable.And John Humphrys’ opening curveball on Saturday’s Celebrity Mastermind: “Name ” “Bez.” “Occupation ” Pass.This Morning, Holly Willoughby: “What should a ‘support neighbour’ look like  ’Cos my mum’s older than me.”Andyour mum isn’t older than you, self-isolate immediately.THIS week’s winner is Future Stewie, from Family Guy, and Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty.All those self-defined “experts” whose coronavirus response is framed not by their humanity or expertise but the desperate need to be proved right.Every selfish moron in the country being filmed panic-buying toilet rolls.Firebrand left-wing stand-up Guz Khan taking the gig economy advertising shilling from Uber Eats.The comically awful use of Photoshopped throwback pictures in BBC drama The Split.And the never-ending queue of fantasists and egomaniacs at E’s Sex Clinic, like third person-speaking Drew, who announced: “I’m not having vanilla sex. That’s not what the Drew brand is about. Le’s too short, man.” The shorter the better . . . man.The Sex Clinic, Matt: “I think I need to learn to love myself.”Five Guys A Week, Glen: “My talents aren’t obvious. They’re not tangible things.” On account of the fact they don’t exist. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trust health service staff coronavirus
story: All along he has followed the best advice of our foremost experts on ­epidemics. They said that would evolve as the situation worsened — and yesterday it was toughened dramatically.National unity is key. We must take to heart the self-isolation and lockdowns — both for those already with symptoms and those without. Likewise the “advice” not to go to pubs, restaurants or cinemas.Our lives will be very dferent for months. Britain will barely resemble the country we love. But we can all play our part in seeing off this catastrophe, minimising the disease’s spread and giving the NHS every chance to save lives.The Sun will raise just one doubt:It still seems inconsistent that families must avoid non-essential social contact, but continue packing the children off to school. We know the NHS would be hit hardhealth workers stayed home to look after their kids. But a school skeleton staff could surely supervise them.Only the wartime generation has experienced a crisis this grave. We have to put our faith politically in the newly elected government tasked with facing it down — and the experts around them.Even more importantly we must trust our health service and back its magnicent and selfless staff. You can do that today by emailing iloveNHS@the-sun or by using the form below. We’ll print your messages.The NHS will need every ounce of support the nation can give, evenit just means dutully staying put in our homes.  THE six days since the Budget seem like ten years.Chancellor Rishi Sunak’s admirable debut last Wednesday is all but irrelevant. Its apparently huge bailouts to mitigate the virus will be nowhere near enough. Its growth forecasts are toast.Britain’s decisive response, including the Bank of England slashing the base rate hours earlier, was praised around the world. Others followed suit. But vastly more will now be needed.Evenit lasts no more than a few months — still a big— Covid- is a gargantuan shock to the global economy.Hundreds of thousands of healthy businesses here face oblivion. Their workers may face the dole. Major ­airlines could go bust within weeks.The Government will have to borrow staggering sums to keep them afloat — dishing out grants, tax breaks, business rates relief, interest-free loans, boosted sick pay and more.But we will add this: This is a ­calamity we must ALL face together.If corporations make staff take the pain while fatcat execs sail through it financially unscathed, there will be hell to pay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: inside airbnb coronavirus isolation gas masks
story: The Corrugated Cottage in sleepy Baltonsborough, Somerset, was once used by land girls - and its owner has refurbished it to make it appear that little has changed since Britain fought against Hitler.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesVisitors considering self-isolating - as well as those who just enjoy history - can still book the cosy lodgings for £ per guest per night for the next four months.Owner Michael Chapman initially used the property as an office, but decided to embrace the buildings history after chancing on some old newspapers from June .He discovered the house had been built in the spring of  for the Womens Land Army.Members supported the war effort by working in local farms.The cottage had eight beds across two bedrooms - although theres now a four-guest maximum because the address has just one bathroom.Theres also an Anderson bomb shelter in the back garden. Home owners installed shelters during the war to protect from the threat of the Nazi Luftwaffe.The propertys Airbnb listing notes: The cottage has been recreated in the style of the s, with authentic details such as a forties enamelled range with back boiler, utility furniture and Bakelite switches and plugs.The kitchen includes an original fties sink, larder and fridge.In the bathroom is a claw-foot roll top bath and toilet with overhead cistern.There is a record player and a selection of LPs from the era to get you in the mood.The property is just an -minute drive from Pilton, where Glastonbury musical festival is held.The festival is set to go ahead this summer, despite fears over Covid-.

title: brits uk travel advice coronavirus raab
story: Dominic Raab told the entire nation to stay put unless it is absolutely essential - cancelling all holidays and trips - as he updated the countrys travel advice this afternoon.Yesterday the EU said it would ban all external travel for a month to try to stop the spread of the virus - along with countries around the world, leaving millions stranded.The Foreign Secretary said he didnt want any more people to be stuck overseas with no way of getting home, as flights get cancelled and routes shut down.He told MPs in the House of Commons: With immediate effect Ive taken the decision to advise British nationals against non essential travel globally, for an initial period of  days and of course subject to ongoing review.He added: UK travellers abroad now face widespread international border restrictions and lockdowns in ious countries.The speed and range of those measures across other countries isIts unclear exactly how long the lockdown would be for in the long run, but it means flights will likely be cancelled for weeks.However, todays FCO update will make it far easier for Brits to get refunds on their travel insurance.The Government said it was still up to members of the public to make decisions on whether they should fly abroad or not.They stressed that anyone thinking of travelling should check their insurance policies and whether they would be valid.But anyone looking to try and come back to the UK should try and do so as soon as possible, while flights are still running.Repatriating everyone at the current time would be unrealistic.Today airports warned they would have to shut within weeks unless they received urgent help from the Government.Boris Johnson told Cabinet this morning the UK was engaged in a war against the disease which we have to win.Todays news comes as:Ryanair, Virgin and EasyJet have cut flights by  per cent this month and IAG has decreased capacity by  per cent.And Ryanair has already warned they may have to ground all of their flights due to the dramatic spread of the deadly disease.Staff have already been laid off or told to take unpaid leave for the next eight weeks.In the last week a huge  changes have been made to FCO Travel Advice – more than in the entirety of .Mr Raab also told the Commons the Government will continue to do everything in our power to get British nations back home.But he stressed every situation was complicated, and could take come time.However, it was warned that Brits could face trouble getting their money backflights are not cancelled.Alana Gomez, spokesperson for flight-comparison site www.jetcost, said: The problem that arises here is that airlines are not necessarily compelled to cancel flights in these circumstances, which can lead to issues with compensation.If your flight is cancelled then you should be able to claim a refund direct from the airline , butit is still running and you do not fly, then the problem needs to be raised with travel insurance companies or credit card providers, though sadly there is no guarantee there.The Foreign  Commonwealth Officedoes not lay out exactly what the phrase means.Instead,  FCO says: whether travel is essential or not is your own decision. You may have urgent family or business commitments to attend to. Circumstances dfer from person to person.In its travel advice guidance, the FCO goes on to say only an inidual can make the decision as to whether travel is essential.In other words, it is up to a person to determine whether travel is important enough to override  travel advice.Now the FCO guidelines have changed, they may refund you anyway.INSURANCEIf that doesnt work, you can speak to your insurer to sort out a refund.But youll only be coveredthe insurance was purchased before the FCO advice was changed.Plenty of insurance providers stopped offering coronavirus cover after the World Health Organisation declared the crisis a pandemic on March .This means you might not be coveredyou booked last minute after then.CREDIT CARD REFUNDIf you paid by credit card, you should be able to get the money back through Section  laws as long as you paid between £ and £,.Section  credit card rules protect customers, for instance in the event of a cancellation.To make a claim, contact your credit card provider - your first port of call should be its customer services phone number - and tell them you want to make a claim under Section .It should then send you a claim form which you can fill in.Weve explained everything you need to knowyour flights have been cancelled due to coronavirus.Here is everything to knowyou want to cancel your holiday. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits working home snaps cats dogs
story: And, as these sweet snaps show, animals will do anything to try to distract their hard-working owners.From the big dog who believes hes the size of a tiny puppy, to the hedgehog perfectly-sized for a desk drawer, animal lovers have been sharing some hilarious photos of their attempts to work from home.One social media user even tweeted a photograph of her pet GOAT curiously inspecting her laptop.Railways and major roads have fallen silent across the country after Boris Johnson warned office staff to work from home where possible.It comes following fears Britain could be locked down over the coronavirus, just like in France, Italy and Spain.Those who live and work in London are particularly vulnerable as the city is the worst-hit place in the UK with  cases, the prime minister said.Nationally, the death toll leapt from  to  today.Schools have been told to send kids with a cough home to stop the spread.It was also reported that up to eight million people could be hospitalised during an outbreak lasting up to a year.

story: THE Queen is to leave Buckingham Palace and step down from several future engagements to remain at Windsor Castle amid the Coronavirus epidemic, royal officials have announced.Her Majesty will title: ibiza majorca coronavirus lockdown hotels closed and airports shut brit tourists told to go home
story: ISLAND leaders in Majorca and Ibiza have announced the closure of ports and airports in the Balearics as part of the battle against coronavirus.President of the Balearic Government, Francina Armengol confirmed the very restrictive measures moments ago.About , tourists are still in the islands.The president said: Departure flights from the Balearic Islands will be allowed so that tourists canto the peninsula or to their country. The fewer people there are in the Islands, the less risk of contagion and the more protected we will be.It will allow us to concentrate on cases of coronavirus that are in our territory and in this way will help the health, personal and economic effort and sacrice being made by the whole of Mallorca, Menorca, Ibiza and Formentera society.There are currently  positive coronavirus cases and one death in the Balearics, as  new cases were reported today.The president has banned any type of flight, commercial or private, with the Balearic Islands from any national airport regardless of national or international origin.Passengers landing from regular line vessels connecting to the islands, with the exception of freight are also prohibited.Residents who are outside the Balearics at the moment canand air mobility in the event of a catastrophe in very exceptional situations would be allowed, such as cases of postponed medical treatment or essential work, especially for the maritime connections, so that the supply of the islands is guaranteed at all times.Airlines can operate only one daily flight to Palma from Madrid, Barcelona and Valencia. Airlines operating from Barcelona and Madrid with Ibiza and Menorca fall under the same restrictions, as will inter-island flights, who are only allowed to do one round trip per day.Special flights are ordered to have safe separation spaces between passengers, reducing capacity.In the case of shipping companies, only the regular line between Ibiza and Formentera can operate with passengers, with three connections a day in each direction.Passengers looking for special flights will have to justy the need to make the trip or their residence to the islands.The Spanish Government now has the power to carry out sanitary control measures for all passengers and travellers entering the archipelago with the aim of preventing new infections coming from outside.The President yesterday ordered the closure of all hotels and holiday rentals over the next few days.President Armengol said: We need to stop the expansion of the virus. story: BORIS Johnson dropped a heavy hint tonight that schools WILL close within days after k people signed a petition urging him to keep kids at home during the coronavirus outbreak.Parents are already choosing to keep their kids off school, and now the Prime Minister has hinted he is considering closing them.Asked today about kids staying at home due to the killer bug, the PM admitted he completely understood parents concerns.The PM said: I understand completely where people are at with that, were keeping it under continuous review.Mr Johnson also insisted free school meals would be protected for students no longer going.He said: As we come to the decision on schools we will have plans ready to go on that, Gavin Williamson education secretary has a plan to make sure that parents with kids who are eligible for free school meals get the compensation or the treatment they need one way or another.No sources also said they were in discussions about whether to postpone crucial exams.Downing Street suggested there could be a skeleton service where the kids of key workers such as NHS staff will continue to be taught to allow their parents to carry on working.A No source said: There has got to be a way of ensuring key workers get to work.It comes as a petition demanding the Government “#closetheschools” amassed hundreds of thousands of signatures.It says: “We would like the government to at least consider closing schools colleges down in the coming weeks or as soon as possible, in addition to taking necessary actions to prevent further spread.“We would like the Government or Parliament to enforce this action due to the growing fear among parents and students that attend school.“The ability to focus or concentrate is affected in addition to the growing fears of the Corona-virus.“In our view, the government and health officials around the world are more reactive rather than proactive. This will result in more spread as time is given for the virus to do so.”It comes as the PM said we are engaged in a war against the disease which we have to win.He and Chancellor Rishi Sunak said they would do whatever it takes to support the economy during this vital time.Extra measures to keep the sinking economy afloat included:Teachers have also bashed staying open, revealing schools were short on staff and kids were staying home.Katharine Birbalsingh, headmistress of Michaela Community School in Wembley, north-west London, said: “Non-essential contact for everyone except for teachers who should congregate with several hundred or even thousands daily “I’m no virologist but how do I make sense of this to staff  Also, dozens hundreds of parents are too scared to send kids in to school!”Andrew O’Neill, head teacher of All Saints Catholic College in west London, said the situation was “unbelievable”.He explained  per cent of his pupils had not turned up and a quarter of his teachers were now in self isolation.For all the latest news, tips and information - title: coronavirus supermarket panic lockdown
story: THIS is the shocking moment shoppers brawl over toilet paper and panic buy booze amid coronavirus chaos.Dozens of customers were captured fighting with each other for loo roll in a Home Bargains store in Nottingham.Desperate staff could be seen screaming at the yobs as they crushed other shoppers to get their hands on new stock.One young woman frantically clung on to packets of toilet paper as stampeding thugs wrestled the product from under her.Other stunned workers were heard calling for calm after the brawl erupted at the budget store yesterday.Social media users have compared the panic buyers to animals after the footage was shared online.One user wrote: “They look like animals!”While another said: “I hope they are all giving each other coronavirus. title: good coronavirus news from across the world
story: CORONAVIRUS is sweeping the globe with European lockdowns, a rising death toll and scores of Brits encouraged to work from home.But in among the chaos, teams of scientists are working to tackle the killer bug, heroic medics are working tirelessly to help others and people are recovering - in huge numbers.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news and updatesCoronavirus has struck fear into almost every Brit, with , cases across the UK and  people dead.The killer flu is rapidly spreading across the globe with , people infected and , deaths.Italy and Spain have imposed unprecedented lockdowns, with police roaming streets ready to turn anyone out and about back to their homes and schools, universities, bars and restaurants closed.Similarly in Ireland pubs have been shut with most working from home.Several states in America have imposed similar measures and brought in emergency protocols to slow the spread. And now scores of countries have closed their borders or imposed travel bans on the worst-hit areas.In the UK, Boris Johnson yesterday advised us to avoid pubs and work from home where possible.The world over, snaps have emerged showing eerily quiet streets and once buzzing cities now looking like ghost-towns.But while its easy to get wrapped up in coronavirus chaos with cases increasing in neighbouring countries at an alarming rate, and some Brits stranded in quarantine zones - its not all bad.Heres a roundup of all the good news coming out of the pandemic.The worlds youngest coronavirus patient, a newborn who was likely infected shortly after birth is said to be out of danger and recovering well.The tiny baby was tested minutes after birth at North Middlesex Hospital.But now the tot is doing well, with experts also suggesting mums and babies struck down by the virus, including pregnant women are low-risk and will most likely only suffer mild symptoms.Wuhan medics were seen celebrating and removing their protective gear after the final coronavirus hospital was shut down - because it no longer had enough cases.China built up  crisis bases within weeks of the killer flu tearing through the country, but have today recorded just one case.Medics at the Sawai Man Singh Hospital in Jaipur have succeeded in curing coronavirus patients with a mix of HIV, swine flu, and Malaria meds.SMS medical college principal and controller, Dr Sudhir Bhandari said: “We provided her treatment following standard protocol and now she has tested negative for the disease, which is a major achievement for SMS Hospital doctors.”A granny who was struck down by the killer flu in the city at the centre of the outbreak has made a full recovery.The -year-old woman, Zhang Guangfen was cured in less than a week because she didnt have any underlying health conditions, docs say.The first person in New Delhi to be struck down with the flu has fully recovered, praising hero medics who looked after himFollowing treatment at Safdarjung hospital, he said: There is no need to be scared. It is just like normal flu.If a healthy person reaches the doctor, our health system is well-equipped, one of the best in the world.Japanese drugmaker Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. said it was developing a new coronavirus drug derived from the blood plasma of people who have recovered from Covid-.The theory is based on research from the Ebola outbreak and avian flu, and incredibly medical literature dating back to  on curing Spanish flu.Following a complete lockdown in Italy, Venetians have shared incredible snaps of the citys canals running completely clear.Tiny silver fish can be seen swimming through the crystal-clear water, with the suggestion that a lack of boat-traffic has reduced the number of pollution in the canals.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus thinking revive blitz spirit
story: People have lost loved ones and will continue to do so, and the virus is going to cause an unprecedented, global economic crisis that could see businesses go under, job losses, and severe financial dficulty for those already living hand to mouth.You’ll no doubt have read the latest bad news.So, solely for the purposes of this article, forgive me , instead, I focus momentarily on trying to find the admittedly few green shoots poking through the rubble.For, unlike Brexitwhich caused bitter ision among communities, the coronavirus pandemicis already bringing communities together that, in the modern age of “smart” devices absorbing our attention, had perhaps become slightly detached from each other in recent years.Professor Steven Taylor, author of The Psychology of Pandemics, says: “People need reminding that they can cope with this. They are resilient. You aren’t going to like it, but you’ll get through it.“You can compare it to the Blitz. People got through the Blitz. It was very stressful but they did it.”My elderly mother lives just a few roads away from me and, like so many with similarly vulnerable relatives, I’m making sure she’s OK.“Just pop a tin of Spam through the letterbox, and I’ll be fine,” she joked in reference to her time growing up during World War Two.But yesterday, three of her immediate neighbours — one of whom she’s never met — put notes through her door to say she should give them a callshe needed anything.In times of such crisis, our first thought is naturally of ourselves and our immediate loved ones.But it seems the upsideof the world slowing down and re-grouping might be that, no longer distracted by the busyness of our normal working days, we will “look up” and “reach out”, as they say in business circles, to those in our communities who might need help.There are plenty of people who already do sterling work in their area, but the onslaught of the coronavirus will perhaps lead to everyone now doing their bit.Quite right too. But the onus can’t solely rest on the shoulders of iniduals, so it’s only right the Government has stepped up to offer some practical help to businesses that will suffer throughout the coming weeks and months.Boris Johnson’s advice that people shouldn’t go to pubs cafes theatres etc is understandable in health terms, but will leave businesses facing a critical downturn in custom through no fault of their own.Yesterday, London restaurateur James Chiaini urged him to “crack open the war chest” and allow local businesses to stay afloat while simultaneously channelling efforts towards helping out in their immediate communities, and it seems that new Chancellor Rishi Sunak has listened.In James’s case, he has staff on hand and lots of food supplies, so instead of shutting down because there are no customers, he and other restaurants across the country could potentially now operate a batch-cooking and delivery service for those in need.Equally, the skill sets of many other businesses can be channelled into providing much-needed, state-funded help where it’s required.And the Government shouldn’t stop there. It should repurpose certain facilities too.Last week, it was reported that the £million Defence Medical Rehabilitation Centre in Loughborough, Leics, is currently seriously underused because only current personnel can access it and only  have done so in the past  months.Madness. At the very least, it should be thrown open to all injured veterans who currently have to go through the overstretched NHS.Or how about temporarily repurposing it as a treatment centre for anyone who could benefit from its facilities, thereby alleviating some of the pressure on local hospitals The Government is clearly in uncharted territory right now because it is dealing with an unprecedented situation.But a continuation of joined-up thinking on how best to get us through this critical phase in our history will ensure that Britain’s enviable “Blitz spirit” is encouraged and kept strong for as long as it needs to be.PRINCE Harry is now back behind the closed doors of his rented Canadian mansion, licking his wounds after his public humiliation at the hands of phone pranksters.During a chat with what he thought was climate change activist Greta Thunberg and her father, Harry pledged his support to the non-existent island of “Chunga-Changa” and failed to question why the hoaxers wanted to ship penguins to the North Pole when they’re actually native to the South Pole.Poor Harry.Still, it perhaps explains why, despite attending Eton, he got D at geography A level.Indeed, on all our faces in these challenging times.Heartfelt congratulations to her and husband Chris.FORMER All Saints star Nicole Appleton has given birth to her second child, a girl called Skipper, at the age of .“After hiding my pregnancy for the last nine months – which was so dficult and keeping her a secret from all my friends – I can finally announce our incredible news!” she wrote on Instagram.Fascinating. It’s one thing wearing a big coat out in public, but how do you hide a growing bump from “friends” Has Nicole, whose boyfriend is Stephen Haines, been in pre-emptive self-isolation for the past few months Or is it simply that her petite frame and enviably taut stomach muscles meant she just looked like the rest of us after a big meal Personally speaking, by month seven I looked like I had a medicine ball stuffed up my frock.STORMZY reportedly ripped up his travel plans after meeting Victoria’s Secret model Yasmine Aisha Khala Holmgren backstage at a gig in Stockholm.The pair are said to have holed up in a hotel room for two days where, according to a friend of the grime star, they wanted to spend “quality time” together.That’s one way of putting it.A NEW biography about former Commons Speaker John Bercow claims that he didn’t speak to a female aide for the entirety of a nine hour flight – because he was furious that his toothpaste had been confiscated at airport security.Quite what it had to do with her is anyone’s guess.But one imagines she was grateful for the prolonged period of peace.HANNAH SMITH, a -year-old mum of one, has been handed a suspended sentence after admitting the crime of harbouring a criminal.Her boyfriend, violent robber Luke Harvey, scaled the wall of HMP Sudbury in Derbyshire, where Hannah was waiting to drive him to Skegness for a weekend away.They were later pulled over by police and Harvey, , had ten months added to the -year sentence he received in .Leicester Crown Court was told that the couple had now split up.Presumably, actually spending time together proved too much.HERE is yet another photograph of the singer and actress Jenner Lopez looking sensational at . Sigh.Apparently, this latest photo-shoot, which highlights her enviably toned and tanned legs in a tuxedo-style leotard, is to promote her new footwear line.Is she wearing shoes We hadn’t noticed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: france ban brits uk coronavirus lockdown made tougher
story: BRITISH nationals will be banned from Francethe UK fails to use the same radical coronavirus containment measures being enforced by EU countries.During a live TV address from Paris on Tuesday evening, French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe expressed extreme frustration that Britain was lagging behind in the war against the deadly illness.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesEveryone within the European Union must adopt coherent methods and processes to fight the epidemic, as in Italy, France and Spain, he said‘It goes without saying thatneighbouring states such as the United Kingdom spend too long continuing to avoid these containment measures, then we would have dficulty accepting British nationals who would move freely in their own country and then come to our country.Mr Philippe was speaking on the first day of a nationwide lockdown in his own country, which has seen major cities including Paris grind to a halt.Such a ban will cause huge problems for the millions of British nationals who have professional and personal links with France.The British make up the biggest foreign visitor group to Paris, which is normally the most popular tourist city in the world.While restrictions on movement and lestyle are growing every day in EU countries, post-Brexit Britain is perceived to be lagging behind.France has ordered bars and restaurants to shut down, for example, while in the UK managers can make their own decision.On Monday, President Emmanuel Macron pledged to put €billioninto the war against coronavirus.There are currently , police and gendarmes officers enforcing draconian restrictions, which include everybody needing an official document to leave the house.Fines for anyone caught without these ‘attestations’ will rise to the equivalent of around £ on Wednesday.Mr Macron said: Walking, meeting friends in the park or in the street will no longer be possible.It is a question of limiting as much as possible all contact beyond the home. title: vera lynn blitz spirit coronavirus
story: WARTIME favourite Dame Vera Lynn has urged Brits to invoke the spirit of the Blitz to beat the coronavirus threat.Forces sweetheart Vera, who boosted troops’ morale by singing for them during World War Two, urged people to keep calm and follow the Government’s advice to overcome the crisis.Her rallying cry came as pranksters added a face mask to a statue of wartime Prime Minister Winston Churchill in Woodford Green, East London.Dame Vera, who will be  on Friday and who is mum to Virginia, , said: “In these uncertain times, I am taken back to my time during World War Two, when we all pulled together and looked after each other.“It is this spirit that we all need to find again to weather the storm of the coronavirus. It’s important to remain positive, keep calm and follow the sensible advice provided by the Government at this dficult time.“I am sure many people, especially the elderly, are worried about what the future may hold. I encourage you all to keep smiling through. Evenwe are isolated in person, we can still be united in spirit.“As the war showed us so many years ago, we are all stronger than we think and, however desperate things may seem today, remember that we can still be kind, we can still laugh — and we can still sing.”Elsewhere, central London’s Savoy Hotel has been forced to close because of the Covid- virus.Staff were called to a meeting on Monday where they were told they were likely to be made redundant.Bosses told workers the hotel will close next Friday for up to four months.The hotel stayed open in an act of defiance during the war and maintained its high ­standards, with guests enjoying food prepared by some of the world’s finest chefs.Winston Churchill was a regular visitor and held conferences there.But it has failed to defeat the virus. One staff member said: “The management team pulled all the hotel staff in for a meeting on Monday to tell us. We were in shock.“This hotel prides itself on its values and its typical British stf upper lip. They stayed open during the war and kept their standards up — but now they’ve decided to close.“I understand safety to public and I understand the risks but the way they have treated the staff after the ­levels of exceptional service we have given them is disgusting.Tap to see where COVID- is near you “The staff are having their own meetings to try and deal with this as our lives are crashing down within the next ten days.“Some of them have decided not to come back already and others are talking about ­staging a walk-out to leave the hotel in trouble at a busy time.”Another worker said: “It has just come totally out of the blue and they haven’t given us a thought whatsoever.“These bosses here, they are well paid, they can afford to do this and not think about us, but this is my only source of income and it isn’t much.“I live pay cheque to pay cheque and now I won’t be able to afford my rent.I don’t know what I’m going to do — I can’t even fly back to my home country to see my parents because of the virus.”When approached by The Sun, the hotel did not deny the claims and said “further announcements” were imminent.Boss Philip Barnes said yesterday: “The welfare of our colleagues and guests is a paramount concern.“The implications of Covid- are wide-ranging for our business and industry as a whole.In accordance with legislation, we are in consultation with our title: female narwhals attracted biggest horns
story: And narwhal fellas like to wave their tusks about as “a sexual weapon” when fighting other males over females.Zackary Graham made the discovery after studying  years of horn size data compared to body size of  adult male narwhals.When comparing iniduals of the same age, sexually selected traits often exhibit disproportional growth - that is, for a given body size, sexually selected traits are often larger than expected in the largest iniduals.Importantly, they compared the growthof the tusk to the scaling relationship between body size and a trait that is unlikely to have sexual s. To do so, they used the tail of the narwhals, called the fluke.Zackary, of Arizona University, said: “The narwhal tusk is a sexually selected signal that is used during the male-male tusking contests.The information that the tusk communicates is simple: ‘I am bigger than you’.”The narwhal is a medium-sized species of whale with a large tusk that ies from in to more than ft — earning it the nickname the “unicorn of the seas”.In fact it is not a true tusk but an enlarged spiral-shaped canine tooth that pushes through the narwhal’s flesh.The findings were published online by the journal Biology Letters.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: driver speeding tickets overturned leaves
story: School milk delivery driver Keith Peace, , was shocked to be hit with a driving ban and £ in fines.But he beat the tickets after producing pictures showing plants growing over the speed signs.Mr Peace, , knew the road was covered by average speed cameras but believed it was a mph zone.Prosecutors at Mold crown court, North Wales, looked at his photographs of the road in Chester and decided not to block his appeal.Prosecutor Ryan Rothwell said: “I have no other evidence to produce and am taking a pragmatic approach.”He had seen photographs produced by Mr Peace, of Barnsley, South Yorks, and it “seemed possible” there was some obstruction.Mr Peace, who now works in a warehouse, said there were no houses or lighting along the road.He added: “If I had seen mph signs then I would not have driven at mph.”The court overturned his disqualication and said the fines would not need to be paid. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The young crime-fighter — identied only as Ellen — wanted to assist police.Quick-thinking Ellen took to sketching the suspect while an officer was taking a statement from her parents over the raid.And she hopes the picture will lead to the crook’s arrest.Humberside Police tweeted a picture of the e-fit and asked members of the publicthey had seen the suspect who, they added, “belongs behind bars”.They said the “helpful” image created by Ellen will make sure cops find the man responsible.Humberside Police officers tweeted: “#HullTeamPatrol PC Suddaby was taking a burglary statement from parents whilst Ellen helpfully drew this picture of the suspect.”Family friend Paul Coulson urged anyone who sees a man resembling the e-fit to tell cops.He tweeted: “This is my friend’s daughter’s drawing of a burglary suspect.“If you see him skulking around the streets of Hull please report him to @Humberbeat.“I can report that Ellen did get some sweets as did PC Suddaby. title: pregnant dog hugs baby monkey
story: The pooch appears to have adopted the infant after his relatives were poisoned by locals for apparently destroying crops.Prakash Badal , who captured the heart-warming bond at a village near Himachal Pradesh in India, said: “The monkey infant seemed to be about  days old when locals poisoned the adult monkeys because it is said they are destroying their crops.“This infant survived and the dog adopted it.“Although sometimes there are conflicts between monkeys and dogs, the relationship of a mother is more important.“I felt that when a mother saw a baby who is very small and left alone and there is nobody to take care of him, the maternal instinct took initiative to adopt a small baby evenit’s from dferent species.“This type of relationship is a lesson for humans who have become selfish and kill each other just because he is from another cast or religion.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast spring to finally kick with 15c calmest weekend of year met office says
story: After a few days of damp and drizzle this Mothering Sunday weekend will be the calmest of the year.The week to come will be pretty mild all round and mostly cloudy, with erratic rain heading south from Wednesday morning and petering out by Friday.Tomorrow will see rain in the midlands and a nice dry spell for the south and Scotland, in a classic soggy sandwich.We are likely to see a centimetre of rain at most in the midlands and a little light drizzle everywhere .Expect a grey and damp Thursday as the rain leans south under a fair bit of cloud cover, getting increasingly erratic as it does so.Those north of the band of rain can finally expect a little sun as it slowly slips down the spine of England.That band of rain and cloud will keep things cool and a little damp for most of us as we head into the weekend.Temperature-wise were looking at some frosty nights, particularly in the north, and a bit of wind whipping around the south coast that will make it feel a bit nippy all round.BEAT energy price rises year after year with Switchcraft. Its free and it could save you an average of £ a year.News UK has a brand partnership with Switchcraft.A Met Office spokesman said: Temperatures will be a degree or two below average for this time of year and it will struggle to climb past C in most places, so it will still be a bit chilly.This weekend is going to be the blissful definition of mild spring weather as we head on to Mothers Day.Expect fine sunshine and the calmest weather we have had all year, and a nice warming high of C in some places.

title: joe biden wins florida democratic presidential primary by huge margin over fidel castro praising bernie sanders
story: The former vice-presidents wins comes as the Unites States is dealing with the frightening coronavirus pandemic.The win marks the third consecutive week Biden piled up wins after his South Carolina victory last month revived his once-weakened campaign.Bernie Sanders recent comments about Cuba probably doomed him there weeks ago, well before Bidens South Carolina surge.In a  Minutes interview on February , Sanders praised Cuban dictator Fidel Castro for his massive literacy program.The -year-old Vermont senator has continued to push on in the  presidential race despite a string of losses to Biden.Last week, Sanders vowed to do everything in his power to stop Donald Trump, who he slammed as a pathological liar and the most dangerous president in modern US history in his six-minute televised address in Vermont.Starting this week, Biden will be receiving Secret Service protection after being repeatedly hassled by protesters.On Monday, the -year-old politician encouraged voters in a telephone town hall to participate in Tuesdays primaries safely.He said: “I appreciate everyone bearing with us as we figure out all the logistics of campaigning in a new way here.Ohio, Louisiana, Georgia, Kentucky and Maryland have already moved to push back their primaries after officials reported problems and the coronavirus continues to spread across America.Other states may follow as more than , people have contracted the deadly disease in the US.Health officials have announced that the number of Americans who have died from coronavirus in the US has surpassed .Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: regular nappers are happier and more productive than non nappers
story: A new study of , Americans examined respondents’ napping preferences and the personality traits associated with those who nap and those who do not.The results showed self-identied nappers were more likely to identy as a productive person – at  percent compared to  percent of non-nappers.And napping may be the key to a better le overall, too self-identied nappers were more likely to also identy as a happyand confident person .Conducted by OnePoll on behalf of Mattress Nerd, the survey also found the biggest upside of napping could be your career drive.Three-quarters of self-identied nappers described themselves as a career-driven person, but only  percent of non-nappers said the same.Eighty-three percent of nappers also said they believe they have a healthy work-le balance, compared to just six in  non-nappers.Napping may be so beneficial, in fact, that over half of all respondents surveyed said they’d be willing to take a pay cutthey could take naps at work.This comes as no surprise either, as the results found  percent of nappers are so dedicated to the cause, they even consider it a hobby of theirs.No wonder — overall, nappers said they feel relaxed , happyand energizedafter catching a snooze.However, nearly a quarter also admitted that they often wake from a nap confused or not even knowing where they were.Of those self-described non-nappers,  percent said their top reason for shying away from a quick snooze is that they can’t get comfortable enough and another three in  said they worry they won’t be able to go to sleep later on.The dficulty people face when trying to take a nap is no joke – one in three respondents said they would be willing to go back in time and relive high schoolit meant they acquired the ability to doze off whenever and wherever taking a successful nap may be solved with a few small tweaks, though.The survey found the prime time to take a nap is . pm and you should do so at a room temperature of  degrees.While it’s really title: nine month old boy coronavirus
story: In the first case, nine-month-old Cassian Coates was rushed to hospital by his worried parents because he had a cold and fever.His parents, Myroslava and Callum Caotes, were then stunned when staff put a “big sign up” near them which read “suspected case”.She said a nurse walked past them in Manchester and gave them the terrying news by saying: “Yeah, that’s you guys”.Cassian, who is just nine-months-old, was then assessed by a doctor who confirmed he had the symptoms and said: “Yeah, it’s the coronavirus strand.”The news of Cassians diagnosis came just hours before a baby at the James Paget University Hospital in Norfolk was confirmed to have the killer bug.The baby was one of three patients who have been diagnosed with COVID- at the hospital in Great Yarmouth and the trio remain in isolation.Describing the moment her son was diagnosed in Manchester, Mrs Coates told Sky News: “When we got to the hospital, we had to go through special measures and ring a certain number for them to let us in.The waiting room actually had a big sign up saying suspected case.“Me and my husband were like oh my God, then a nurse walked past and said yeah, thats you guys.“We went in, then the doctor came in with a mask on, did some basic checks, temperature, checked his ears and said yeah, its the coronavirus strand.”Mrs Coates, a mum-of-one, admitted she and her husband first laughed when they were told as they were in disbelief that her son had the killer bug.The family is now in self-isolation at home and she is racking her brains as to how Cassian caught the disease.She added: “We wondered where he caught it because my husband and I are both fine.“I did panic but I cannot express how fantastic and reassuring our GP was. They said that with children this age they are diagnosing by symptoms.“We were told to go home to self-isolate for two weeks and keep giving him Calpol asit was a cold.“There are peaks and troughs but thankfully Cassian is over the worst of it.”It comes as....However, health officials say the most common symptoms of coronavirus infection usually include:Developing these symptoms does not necessarily mean you have the illness and they are similar to other illnesses, such as the common cold or flu.Some people will not develop all of these symptoms -  and some might not even show symptoms at all, experts say.People with fever, cough and dficulty breathing should seek medical attention, the WHO says.Oryou have been in close contact with an infected person.Public Health England defines close contact as being within two metres of someone for  minutes or more or sharing a room for a prolonged period.The NHS has urged people to stay indoors and avoid contact with other people as,you have the virus, you risk spreading it to others.Health experts are warning people not to go straight to your doctors surgery, over fears people will spread the bug there too - but do seek medical help by calling NHS .If you get a cough, a high temperature, or you feel short of breath, continue to follow this advice.Do not leave your house without getting advice from a doctor.In order to reduce your risk of infection, you should:If you have cold-like symptoms, you can help protect others by staying home when you are sick and avoiding contact with others.You should also cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze then throw it away and wash your hands.Cleaning and disinfecting objects and surfaces which you may have touched is also important.The case comes after a newborn baby in London became the world’s youngest coronavirus patient last week.The unnamed mum was rushed to hospital with suspected pneumonia which was only confirmed after the birth.The pair were treated at separate hospitals and it is believed the baby was infected from coughs or sneezes. The boy is now said to be out of danger and recovering.It comes after the UK’s youngest coronavirus victim was last night named as -year-old Craig Ruston - as his devastated we paid an emotional tribute.The amazing father-of-two, from Kettering, Northants, who had motor neurone disease, succumbed to the killer bug in hospital on Monday.In the UK, coronavirus has killed  people while a total of , have been struck down with the illness.Craigs we Sally broke news of the death on her husbands Facebook page Me and my MND.Or you can like our coronavirus Facebook page here: https:www.facebook CoronavirusLatestTheSun Tap to see where COVID- is near youShe said: “My amazing Craig passed away yesterday morning at .am. We are truly heartbroken.Last Tuesday he was taken unwell and we have since spent the last  days in isolation.Craig’s chest infection was confirmed as Covid-.How dare that take Craig who was already facing this , the most vile and evil of diseases.”It comes after Chancellor Rishi Sunak yesterday wrote a £billion cheque to keep families and businesses afloat during the coronavirus crisis and pledged: We will do whatever it takes.However, health officials say the most common symptoms of coronavirus infection usually include:Some patients may have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat or diarrhoea - but these are usually mild and begin gradually.Developing these symptoms does not necessarily mean you have the illness and they are similar to other illnesses, such as the common cold or flu.Some people will not develop all of these symptoms -  and some might not even show symptoms at all, experts say.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus travel border queues europe
story: THE coronavirus has sparked travel chaos across Europe with -mile queues at borders after the EU slammed shut its doors.The deadly outbreak has now infected more than , people and killed , after tearing through the continent.Governments are now taking drastic measures to slow the spread, including lockdowns and travel restrictions.And there was chaos at borders across the EU after countries reintroduced checks across the previously passport-free Schengen Area.Dramatic pictures show queues of lorries and cars tailed back nearly  miles at the frontier between Poland and Lithuania.Janina Stukiene, who was stuck in the traffic with her husband and son, said: “We are all desperate, cold and sleepless here for a third day.“We just want to go home.”Similar traffic jams were visible on the borders with Germany and the Czech Republic.European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said leaders agreed to set up green lanes for trucks and other priority vehicles aimed at beating the jams.Spain, France, Germany and Bulgaria have now all blocked travel even with countries in the free-moving Schengen zone.Border guards were this week seen locking off crossings between Spain and France, Portugal and Spain, and Switzerland and France.At least seven countries – including Austria, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Poland – have now told the EU they have reintroduced ID checks inside Europe’s passport-free Schengen Area.The EU also announced last night it was closing its borders to almost everyone coming from outside the bloc for  days.The  member states agreed to impose bans on tourism and non-essential business “immediately”.Chancellor Angela Merkel said there would be “very, very limited exceptions”.The plan exempts long-term EU residents, diplomats, and some healthcare and transport workers.Merkel said citizens of Britain, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, and Norway are also exempt.The EU leaders also agreed to coordinate the repatriation of EU citizens stranded outside the bloc, she said.In Italy, infections jumped to , on Tuesday. With , deaths, Italy accounts for a third of the global death toll.Spain, the fourth-most infected country, saw its cases rise by more than , in one day to ,.Deaths from COVID- jumped to , a toll that included  elderly residents of a Madrid nursing home who died over five days.Among them was the -year-old diabetic grandmother of Ainhoa Ruiz.Ruiz said: “We feel totally helpless and devastated because my grandma spent her last week only with her husband and caretakers but no other relatives.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: susanna reid good morning britain steve barclay
story: The fuming Good Morning Britain Presenter - who is home for two weeks after her son developed symptoms - laid into the Chief Secretary to the Treasury for failing to keep frontline workers title: girl cushed toilet roll stampede
story: The -year-old girl had been at the Coles store in Perth to stock up on school snacks and loo roll, but was reportedly knocked over and trampled by desperate shoppers hoarding bog roll.Speaking to The Western Australian, the girls mum, Emma - who is currently wheelchair-bound following an operation - said she was disappointed with the other shoppers actions.She said: [My daughter] was pushed to the ground and then stood on by adults who had no care in the world for a child on the floor.People were walking over her while she was crying on the ground just to get what they wanted.The -year-old, named as Hayley by  News was taken for an X-ray after she sustained a swollen knee.Emma continued: Once [the manager] had been told what had happened he took myself and my children straight out the back and got ice to put on my daughters knee.A Coles spokesperson said: Coles takes the wellbeing of our customers and team members seriously and we are constantly reviewing security measures to manage the unprecedented levels of demand we are seeing in our stores.We ask that customers to continue to show compassion towards fellow customers and team members at this challenging time.The shocked mum said she couldnt believe it when she arrived at the store with -year-old Hayley and her nine-year-old son and grown adults were shoving each other  and yelling.She said: I am shocked at how people were acting this morning even before the doors opened.People pushing, people telling people to get back in line.Australia currently has  cases and  deaths.The shocking incident follows similarly dystopian scenes around the world as supermarket shelves are left bare following panic buying and hoarding.In the UK, several supermarkets have imposed limits on the number of items one customer can buy - including on goods people have been stockpiling like loo roll, pasta and and sanitiser.In France the shelves have reportedly been stripped of red wine and condoms as people bolt down for a two-week quarantine.And in the US, two brothers are being threatened with a criminal investigation after buying up thousands of essentials, like hand sanitiser and antibacterial wipes and then selling them on at  times the price.The pair had their Amazon accounts shut down after it was revealed they were marking up hand gel purchased at dollar stores to around  .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
